image.altText: An older couple smile, standing in a kitchen holding kitchen utensils over a pot full of food.

props.synopsis: The latest Foodbank Hunger Report has found 3.4 million households across Australia are experiencing food insecurity, with low income earners having to skip meals or eat less because they cannot afford enough food.

title.children: Two million households in grip of 'severe' food insecurity, annual snapshot shows

image.altText: A man with grey hair and beard leans over bushfire bunker built into ground

props.synopsis: Adelaide Hills father Daniel Katz admits he did not go through the proper channels when building a bushfire bunker at his family home, but now fears he will be forbidden from using the structure even as a last resort.

title.children: Hills resident battling for bushfire bunker approval fears he'll be 'forced to remove' shelter

image.altText: An elderly lady with shoulder length blonde hair and black glasses stares at the camera over her left shoulder

props.synopsis: Grieving mother Jan Edwards was heartbroken when a legal "loophole" stopped her speaking in court after her son was fatally run over by a car. It sparked a fight for change that has reached parliament.

title.children: Grief-stricken mum denied the chance to read victim impact statement takes her fight to parliament

image.altText: Hands holding phones at a social media summit.

props.synopsis: Government leaders, academics, advocates and teenagers met over two days to discuss the impact of social media and how to handle its effects in the future.

title.children: Two states came together to talk about how social media is impacting young people. Here's how it happened.

image.altText: A house auction in Norwood

props.synopsis: It's a matter of when, not if, the Reserve Bank will take the knife to interest rates, but first home buyers may only see a fleeting, and possibly minuscule, improvement in affordability.

title.children: More wealth in fewer hands — the great housing rort

image.altText: People in a packed moshpit inside a tent with giant balloons put their hands up as a person on stage jumps up in the air.

props.synopsis: Freedom of Information documents reveal tens of millions of dollars in grants were given to global behemoth Live Nation at a time when Australia's music industry was struggling.

title.children: Music giant Live Nation earned $US23 billion last year. Australian governments have been giving it millions in grants

image.altText: Dozens of people put their hands in the air at a concert.

props.synopsis: A legal firm says it is investigating allegations of "deceptive, misleading or unconscionable conduct". The ticketing company says it is not responsible for setting prices.

title.children: Ticketmaster and Live Nation could face class action from music fans over 'dynamic' ticket pricing

image.altText: A teenage boy leaning against a wall holds his head in his hands and sobs with anguish

props.synopsis: Residents and refugees in the city of Jabalia are entering their 11th day under fire as part of a renewed push by the Israel Defense Forces. The IDF says it follows intelligence Hamas is "reforming in the area".

title.children: The controversial plan that retired generals think Israel needs for northern Gaza

image.altText: A bearded ranger leans over a map wearing sunglasses, it is a bright sunny day.

props.synopsis: In an age where the smart phone has become the go-to for many of our navigational needs, there are still those who rely on physical maps.

title.children: Paper maps were once the stuff of treasure hunts for Owen, but now they're a big part of his job

image.altText: A woman with dark hair up in braids smiles

props.synopsis: After waking from a week-long coma caused by a cardiac arrest that left her with a hypoxic brain injury, Mel Hartman was so disoriented she thought she "was still a rowdy teenager" — and while she has undergone intensive rehabilitation, she says social supports are lacking.

title.children: When Mel Hartman awoke from a coma at 31, she thought she was a 'rowdy teenager'

image.altText: A white house made of recycled materials with a blue sky behind it.

props.synopsis: Bespoke eco-friendly stays have popped up right across regional South Australia. Industry bodies say they are vital for reinvigorating the tourism industry after a drop in visitor numbers.

title.children: Why eco-stays might be the key to boosting regional tourism amid post-COVID dip

image.altText: A drone that looks like an aeroplane flies through the air.

props.synopsis: Drones have changed the face of modern warfare and are being used from Ukraine to the Middle East, but can Australia keep up with the pace when it comes to its national defence strategy?

title.children: What Australia needs to learn from the drones dominating the Ukraine war

image.altText: Classroom chair knocked over

props.synopsis: Arduous paperwork, surveillance and bullying from management are among the challenges teachers say they face amid a nationwide education staff shortage.

title.children: 'I had a nervous breakdown': Abusive, bullying behaviour behind teaching exodus

image.altText: A person holds a grey Visa card next to a black EFTPOS payment terminal

props.synopsis: There is an end in sight for consumers getting hit with sneaky surcharges when they pay on card, with the federal government prepared to ban the practice by 2026, promising to give consumers and small businesses "a fair go."

title.children: Debit card surcharges to be scrapped by 2026, government promises

props.synopsis: Mental health, technology and artificial intelligence (AI): Here's what hundreds of students, parents and teachers are most concerned about when it comes to education.

title.children: 'The entire system is broken': Hundreds of students, parents and teachers told us their thoughts about education

image.altText: political ads on a mobile phone graphic

props.synopsis: The outcome of two misleading assertions in 2022 reinforces what many in Australia have long suspected — that when it comes to the facts, there is one set of rules for politicians and another for everyone else.

title.children: Labor wants 'fundamental' electoral reform but noticeably absent from its plans are the biggest threats to democracy

image.altText: A silhouetted man stands in front of an inferno, a metal framework visible above it

props.synopsis: The Israeli air force pounded a hospital and food distribution centre in Gaza as well as an apartment building in northern Lebanon, killing and injuring dozens.

title.children: Israeli air strikes kill 32 people across Gaza and northern Lebanon

image.altText: A man's hand encloses an orange ball while blood flows from a needle and tube in his forearm.

props.synopsis: Josh Blizzard has a genetic condition called haemochromatosis, where his body absorbs too much iron. The prescribed treatment is to regularly remove blood, and the good news is it's safe for donation.

title.children: Tens of thousands of '100 per cent safe' bags of blood are being binned instead of donated

image.altText: Sean "Diddy" Combs dressed in a suit and bowtie not smiling

props.synopsis: The latest accusers are among more than 100 other alleged victims who are in the process of taking legal action against the hip hop mogul.

title.children: Six new lawsuits accuse Sean 'Diddy' Combs of assaulting men, women and child

image.altText: People vote in Virginia.

props.synopsis: When Americans turn up to the ballot box next month, it could be the tightest election in more than two decades, according to a US politics expert.

title.children: The upcoming US election could be the closest in more than two decades, expert says

image.altText: A historic photo of a house on wheels.

props.synopsis: The nation-building Snowy Hydro scheme came at a huge cost for the people of Old Adaminaby, some of whom are still lamenting their loss more than 65 years later.

title.children: Decades after the government destroyed their town, residents grapple with progress and bitterness

image.altText: Law Courts of the Australian Capital Territory

props.synopsis: The court found the man's BMW convertible was "substantially over-insured" for more than $130,000, when he'd purchased it for $25,000 a year before the incident.

title.children: Driver jailed after staging car accident as part of $130,000 insurance fraud attempt

image.altText: A herd of sheep in a dry paddock on a farm.

props.synopsis: The federal government will provide an additional $32 million to help WA's sheep industry transition away from live exports, bringing the total support package to $139 million.

title.children: Federal government to provide additional $32 million to cushion WA sheep industry from export ban

image.altText: Claudia Karvan poses for season three of Take 5 with Zan Rowe at the Pleasure Club, Newtown.

props.synopsis: The Australian actor and TV producer explains how her Bali upbringing, salsa, and a love for Sinéad O'Connor have shaped her career and attitude to life.

title.children: 'The world can break your heart': Claudia Karvan knows things are bleak, but these songs give her hope

image.altText: Justin Trudeau shaking hands with Narendra Modi.

props.synopsis: Canada and India expel six of each other's diplomats in tit-for-tat moves as part of an escalating dispute over the June 2023 assassination of a Sikh activist in Canada.

title.children: Canada names Indian ambassador as person of interest in Hardeep Singh Nijjar killing

image.altText: Two women look at a share price board outside the ASX in Sydney.

props.synopsis: New travel data is set to take the temperature of the economy and the ASX is set to open higher on strong US lead. See how the day unfolds on the markets blog.

title.children: New travel data set to take temperature of the economy, ASX set to open higher on strong US lead

image.altText: Woman watching over ICU crib, looking at her baby sleeping.

props.synopsis: Families face an expensive legal battle to prove medical negligence in Australia, but experts say reforms that New Zealand undertook two decades ago offer a solution.

title.children: Australian patients have a hard time proving medical negligence, but in NZ it's a different story

image.altText: A woman holds up a dirt clodded garlic bulb by the stem and smiles at the camera.

props.synopsis: Instead of relying on machines, a garlic farm in the tiny Northern Territory community of Ali Curung has invested in more people power to finish this year's big harvest job.

title.children: Remote garlic farm ditches machines to give more people jobs during harvest

image.altText: Elise Hodder poses during a photo shoot, looking across the camera and seen from side profile.

props.synopsis: The parents of a 24-year-old woman killed when she was struck by a car during a party in a park in Melbourne's eastern suburbs on Sunday morning say she was a "beautiful soul with a radiance that touched everybody".

title.children: Elise Hodder, 24, identified as victim of fatal crash during park party

image.altText: A grey jet in the sky.

props.synopsis: China's military commences a new round of war games near Taiwan, aimed at signalling a stern warning to the island's pro-independence movements.

title.children: China launches military drills around Taiwan as a warning against independence

image.altText: A middle-aged Turkish man with a beard wearing a suit speaks behind a lectern.

props.synopsis: The three laureates were recognised for their work in studying how political institutions are formed, and how they affect prosperity and global inequality.

title.children: Nobel economics prize goes to researchers who showed democratic institutions boost economic growth

image.altText: A man walks through journalists and cameras.

props.synopsis: The Federal Court has heard arguments over whether Mr Lehrmann's appeal against the ruling in his failed defamation case should go ahead.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's lawyer says his only way to make money may be 'to go on OnlyFans'

image.altText: A woman is hugging a golden retriever dog

props.synopsis: Deciding when to end the life of an old or sick pet can be incredibly tough, so many animal owners are now seeking help from bereavement counsellors.

title.children: Pets can be some of our 'greatest loves'. How do we know when to say goodbye?
